overview: The purpose of this Act is to permanently establish the women's court program in the first circuit. [13] It also establishes a two-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [13] The measure requires the judiciary to submit reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's court. [13]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [13] These funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment, and the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the women's court pilot program. [13] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [13]
assumptions_and_methodology: The provided documents do not specify the assumptions and methodology used to determine the appropriation amounts. [13] The funds are allocated for mental health, substance abuse treatment, other services, equipment, and the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [14] The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [13]
agency_impact: There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. [13] The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [13] Your Committee on Conference has amended this measure by requiring the Judiciary to be responsible for providing mental health services under the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit. [14]
economic_impact: The women's court program's goal is diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [13] Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. [13] The services offered by the program shall address areas such as trauma and mental health treatment, life-skills training, and housing support. [13]
policy_impact: This measure permanently establishes the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit by codifying it within the Hawaii Revised Statutes. [14] It establishes a temporary two-year Women's Court Pilot Program within the Kona division of the Third Circuit. [13] Part III of the Act, which establishes the pilot program, shall be repealed on June 30, 2027. [13]
revenue_sources: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [13] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [13] No other revenue sources are mentioned in the provided documents. [13]
six_year_fiscal_implications: This measure permanently establishes the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit, which will have ongoing fiscal implications. [13] It also establishes a two-year women's court pilot program in the Kona division of the third circuit. [13] For the pilot program, the measure appropriates $514,900 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [14] The appropriated funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, other services, equipment, and one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [13] The judiciary is required to submit reports on the pilot program to the governor and legislature prior to the convening of the regular sessions of 2026 and 2027. [13] Recommendations will be made as to whether the pilot program should continue, expand, provide additional services, or be discontinued. [13] The part of the Act establishing the pilot program is set to be repealed on June 30, 2027. [13]
operating_revenue_impact: The provided documents do not indicate any impact on operating revenues. [13] The measure appropriates funds from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for program expenditures. [13] No revenue-generating components are described in the bill. [13]
capital_expenditure_impact: The bill appropriates funds for fiscal year 2025-2026 and fiscal year 2026-2027 for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment. [13] The specific types or costs of the equipment are not detailed in the provided documents. [13] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [13]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The Women's Court Program in the First Circuit is permanently established, which will result in ongoing fiscal obligations beyond the initial six-year period. [13] The two-year women's court pilot program in the third circuit is repealed on June 30, 2027. [13] Any future fiscal implications for the third circuit program will depend on recommendations made in the Judiciary's reports and subsequent legislation. [13]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The duration of the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit has been changed from three years to two years. [14] Specific appropriations of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027 have been established, replacing the previous unspecified amounts. [14] The Judiciary is now responsible for providing mental health services under the pilot program. [14] Language that would have required the Judiciary to submit a report on the need for pilot programs in other circuits has been deleted. [14] The sunset date for the pilot program has been changed to June 30, 2027. [14]
